intro.value: I’m a big sports fan. My wife likes to joke that we’re one of the last millennial households in the country to have a cable subscription. Live sports is the reason. Last winter I was watching an NFL game with one of the league’s most memorably named players: Ha Ha Clinton-Dix. But it wasn’t his first name that caught my attention — it was his last.

I started to think of all the athletes with hyphenated last names that I’ve seen in recent years. The list of players whose names arch over the numbers on the back of their jerseys goes on and on: Clinton-Dix, Shai Gilgeous-Alexander, Sean Reid-Foley. So I wanted to investigate — Are double-barreled last names getting more common in professional sports?
Short answer: Yes. Longer answer: keep reading.

heatmapDek: by decade of entrance into each league

heatmapCopy.value: When I grouped the players by the decade they entered each league a clear trend emerged, especially for the four leagues (MLB, NBA, NFL, and NHL) that had been around since at least the 1950s.
Unsurprisingly, the WNBA is off the charts with stars like Skylar Diggins-Smith Kaleena Mosqueda-Lewis rocking the hyphen. **ADD IN DETAIL**
Check out a league-by-league breakdown below.

vignetteCopy.value: Of course, there’s more to a hyphen than meets the eye. A player can (among other things):

vignetteBullets.value: inherit their double-barreled name from their parents’ already hyphenated names like Ryan Rowland-Smith
combine of both of their parents’ last names like BenJarvus Green-Ellis
get married and combine names with their spouse like Skylar Diggins-Smith
change their name for religious reasons like Kareem Abdul-Jabbar
have a culturally traditional hyphendated name like Jean-Luc Grand-Pierre

vignettes.category: Inherited already hyphenated name from parents
vignettes.text: The MLB didn’t have a player with a hyphenated last name until 2007, when Rowland-Smith took the mound for the Seattle Mariners, and the league’s only had three others since. Rowland-Smith, whose Twitter handle is @hyphen18, inherited his last name from his father, Rob Rowland-Smith, an Australian trainer known as “The Sandhill Warrior.” Rowland-Smith’s now a baseball analyst with his old team, the Mariners. He was again a part of MLB hyphen history when he called a Rangers’ game in May 2018 with both Isiah Kiner-Falefa and Austin Bibens-Dirkx in the lineup — the first time in MLB history that two starters sported hyphens.

Green-Ellis combined his mother’s last name, Green, with his father’s last name, Ellis. As for his first name, his mom just liked how it sounded. Put it all together and you have “The Law Firm.” It’s a fitting nickname for the former NFL running back who thought about going to law school. Green-Ellis spent the 2008-2011 seasons with the New England Patriots and notably never lost a fumble in over 500 carries. Green-Ellis spent a couple of more seasons with the Cincinnati Bengals before making his exit from the league in 2014. He’s still remembered as having one of the best nicknames in sports.

vignettes.category: Married and combined names with spouse
vignettes.text: Diggins-Smith, then just Skylar Diggins, rose to national prominence during the 2010 NCAA women’s basketball championship as a sophomore point guard. She would lead her Notre Dame team to three consecutive Final Four appearances. In 2013 she was drafted into the WNBA, and by 2017 she had added a hyphen to the back of her jersey after marrying longtime boyfriend Daniel Smith. Of the 182 players with double-barrelled last names identified in seven leagues since 1950, 34 combined names with their spouses after marriage. All of these 34 players were women, and all but one played in the WNBA.

Abdul-Jabbar is one of the OG’s of double-barreled last names. When he entered the NBA during the 1969-1970 season, it was as Lew Alcindor. He had converted to Islam in 1968, but didn’t publically begin using his new hyphenated name, which means “noble servant of Allah,” until a few years later in 1971. In his 2017 autobiography, Abdul-Jabbar wrote “People did not want me messing with their idea of who I was or what I represented to them. To many, by changing my religion and name, I was no longer the typical American kid playing a typical American sport, embodying typical American values.”

vignettes.team: Columbus Blue Jackets, Atlanta Thrashers, Washington Capitals
vignettes.text: Grand-Pierre was dubbed the “The Hyphenator” for his double double-barrelled name. The former NHL defenseman is from Quebec, where hyphenated last names are common. French influence places like Canada and Haiti, and New Orleans gives us names like Grand-Pierre’s and the NFL’s Jason Pierre-Paul and Stanley Jean-Baptiste. A few years after Grand-Pierre was born, Quebec also implemented a provincial policy in 1981 that prevented women from legally taking on their husband’s last name. The goal was to promote equality for the spouses, but it also created “generation hyphenation.”

methodsCopy.value: Player names were collected from Baseball Reference, Basketball Reference, Football Reference, Hockey Reference, MLS, and NWLS. Names that included “-” were tagged and manually vetted. Korean names, where the last name appears before the first name, were not tagged as hyphenated names. Players were grouped by the decade in which they entered the league or played in their first professional game. The code for collecting, tagging and cleaning the names is here.
